title: Process Simulation & Control
text:
We will be utilizing the python-control package, which implements basic operations for modeling control systems. Find the documentation for an installation guide and tutorials here.
In this demonstration, we’ll look at a few familiar systems. Consider the following open-loop transfer functions, for two systems under PI-control:
\[L_{1}(s) = \frac{\frac{K_{c}}{1.5}(1.5s+1)}{s(2s+1)(s+1)}\]
\[L_{2}(s) = \frac{\frac{K_{c}}{0.5}(0.5s+1)}{s(2s+1)(s+1)}\]


Recall the point of Bode plots – to visualize how a given transfer function responds to a sinusoidal input, of the form
\[u(t) = A\sin{\omega t + \phi}\]
For a specified amplitude \(A\)$, frequency of oscillation \(\omega\), and phase shift \(\phi\).


Code
import numpy as np
import control as ctrl

s = ctrl.tf('s') # define 's' as a TransferFunction class

intgr = 1/s

diffr = s

ctrl.bode_plot(intgr)

ctrl.bode_plot(diffr)











Code
Kc = 1 # placeholder gain to use in tf construction
tau_I1 = 1.5
tau_I2 = 0.5

Gv = 1 # tf of a gate valve (unity loop)
Gm = 1 # tf of a measurement device (unity loop)

Gp = 1 / ((2*s+1)*(s + 1)) # tf of the process
Gc = Kc * (1 + 1 / (tau_I1*s)) # tf of the controller
Gc2 = Kc * (1 + 1 / (tau_I2*s)) 

Gol = Gv*Gm*Gp*Gc
Gol

Gol

ctrl.root_locus_plot(Gol, initial_gain=1.5)
# ctrl.root_locus_plot(Gol2)


Ignoring fixed x limits to fulfill fixed data aspect with adjustable data limits.
